description: From Middle English scren, screne (“windscreen, firescreen”), from Anglo-Norman escren (“firescreen, the tester of a bed”), Old French escren, escrein, escran (modern French écran (“screen”)), from Middle Dutch scherm, from Old Dutch *skirm, from Proto-West Germanic *skirmi, from Proto-Germanic *skirmiz (“fur, shelter, covering, screen”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ker- (“to cut, divide”).
Cognate with Dutch scherm (“screen”), German Schirm (“screen”). Doublet of scherm.
An alternative etymology derives Old French escren from Old Dutch *skrank (“barrier”) (compare German Schrank (“cupboard”), Schranke (“fence”).

entries.meaning: A physical divider intended to block an area from view, or provide shelter from something dangerous.

definitionGroups.group: A material woven from fine wires intended to block animals or large particles from passing while allowing gasses, liquids and finer particles to pass.

entries.meaning: (mining, quarrying) A frame supporting a mesh of bars or wires used to classify fragments of stone by size, allowing the passage of fragments whose a diameter is smaller than the distance between the bars or wires.
(baseball) The protective netting which protects the audience from flying objects
examples: Jones caught the foul up against the screen.

entries.meaning: (printing) A stencil upon a framed mesh through which paint is forced onto printed-on material; the frame with the mesh itself.

definitionGroups.group: (by analogy) Searching through a sample for a target; an act of screening

entries.meaning: (genetics) A technique used to identify genes so as to study gene functions.

definitionGroups.group: Various forms or formats of information display

entries.meaning: The viewing surface or area of a movie, or moving picture or slide presentation.
The informational viewing area of electronic devices, where output is displayed.
examples: You won't find me living for the screen  […]  I ain't equipment I ain't automatic

entries.meaning: One of the individual regions of a video game, etc. divided into separate screens.
examples: The idea is to reach the 21st level of an enormous network of interlocking screens, each of which is covered with blocks that you bounce along on.

entries.meaning: (computing) The visualised data or imagery displayed on a computer screen.
examples: After you turn on the computer, the login screen appears.

entries.meaning: (figurative) A disguise; concealment.
examples: They'd say he was operating behind a screen of guilelessness and was a superhypocrite.

definitionGroups.group: Definitions related to standing in the path of an opposing player

entries.meaning: (American football) Short for screen pass.
(basketball) An offensive tactic in which a player stands so as to block a defender from reaching a teammate.
(cricket) An erection of white canvas or wood placed on the boundary opposite a batsman to make the ball more easily visible.
(nautical) A collection of less-valuable vessels that travel with a more valuable one for the latter's protection.
(architecture) A dwarf wall or partition carried up to a certain height for separation and protection, as in a church, to separate the aisle from the choir, etc.
(Scotland, archaic) A large scarf.

verbs.description: screen (third-person singular simple present screens, present participle screening, simple past and past participle screened)

entries.meaning: To filter by passing through a screen.
examples: Mary screened the beans to remove the clumps of gravel.

entries.meaning: To shelter or conceal.
To remove information, or censor intellectual material from viewing. To hide the facts.
examples: The news report was screened because it accused the politician of wrongdoing.

entries.meaning: (film, television) To present publicly (on the screen).
examples: The news report will be screened at 11:00 tonight.

entries.meaning: To fit with a screen.
examples: We need to screen this porch. These bugs are driving me crazy.

entries.meaning: (medicine) To examine patients or treat a sample in order to detect a chemical or a disease, or to assess susceptibility to a disease.

(molecular biology) To search chemical libraries by means of a computational technique in order to identify chemical compounds which would potentially bind to a given biological target such as a protein.
(basketball) To stand so as to block a defender from reaching a teammate.
To determine the source or subject matter of a call before deciding whether to answer the phone.
